The White Rabbit: A nervous, perpetually late creature, prone to panicked exclamations and hurried speech, always worried about keeping on schedule.
Alice: A curious, polite, and occasionally stubborn girl, asking endless questions and trying to apply logic to an illogical world.
Bill: A simple, hardworking lizard, often confused and reluctant to get involved in strange situations but too obedient to refuse.


Dialogue History: Alice: But then, shall I _never_ get any older than I am now? That'll be a comfort, one way--never to be an old woman--but then--always to have lessons to learn! Oh, I shouldn't like _that!_
Alice: Oh, you foolish Alice! How can you learn lessons in here? Why, there's hardly room for _you_, and no room at all for any lesson-books!
The White Rabbit: Mary Ann! Mary Ann! Fetch me my gloves this moment!
The White Rabbit: Then I'll go round and get in at the window.
Alice: _That_ you won't!
The White Rabbit: Pat! Pat! Where are you?
Pat: Sure then I'm here! Digging for apples, yer honour!
The White Rabbit: Digging for apples, indeed! Here! Come and help me out of _this!_
The White Rabbit: Now tell me, Pat, what's that in the window?
Pat: Sure, it's an arm, yer honour!

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: The White Rabbit: An arm, you goose! Who ever saw one that size? Why, it fills the whole window!
